name: Wraparound Services
summary: Wraparound Services is a comprehensive, individualized care coordination approach designed to support children, adolescents, and families with complex mental health, behavioral, or social needs.
description: Wraparound Services is a holistic, community-based care model that integrates mental health, social services, educational supports, and family involvement into one individualized plan. The approach emphasizes collaboration across systems (schools, healthcare, child welfare, juvenile justice) and empowers families by centering their strengths and voice in decision-making. A dedicated care coordinator and team—including professionals, family members, and community supports—develop and monitor a plan tailored to the child and family’s needs. Wraparound is designed to reduce fragmentation of services, prevent out-of-home placements, and promote stability and well-being. It is commonly used for children and adolescents with serious emotional disturbances, behavioral challenges, or multi-system involvement.

metadata.equipment_required: None beyond communication and care planning tools
metadata.training_required: Wraparound facilitators and team members require specialized training in care coordination, family engagement, and trauma-informed practices
metadata.session_duration: Ongoing care coordination; meetings typically 60–90 minutes
treatment_duration: 3–12 months or longer, depending on needs

primary_indications: Children and adolescents with serious emotional or behavioral disorders
Youth at risk of out-of-home placement
conditions_treated: Co-occurring mental health and social challenges
contraindications: Families unable or unwilling to participate in collaborative planning
Situations requiring immediate crisis stabilization without system capacity
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and supportive, as it is a non-invasive, team-based intervention. Risks are minimal but may include service delays if coordination is poor.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate to strong evidence base for reducing out-of-home placements and improving family outcomes
clinical_metadata.research_support: Numerous studies support Wraparound’s effectiveness in improving outcomes for high-need youth, reducing hospitalizations, and lowering costs.

sections.text: Wraparound Services function by creating an individualized care plan that integrates input from families, providers, and systems. A facilitator organizes a team around the child and family, ensuring that interventions address clinical, social, educational, and community needs in a coordinated way. By engaging families in decision-making and focusing on strengths, the approach improves engagement, reduces fragmentation, and enhances long-term outcomes.

sections.preparation: Identify eligible child/youth through referral from schools, child welfare, or mental health services. Engage family in process and assign a care coordinator.
procedure: Assemble a wraparound team including family, providers, and community supports.
Develop individualized service plan with measurable goals.
Coordinate services across education, healthcare, social services, and justice systems.
Regularly review and adjust plan with family and team input.
sections.frequency: Weekly or biweekly team meetings plus ongoing care coordination.
sections.duration: 3–12 months or longer depending on family needs.

sections.pre_session: Check-in with family and team about progress and challenges.
sections.treatment_phase: Facilitated team meeting to review goals, update service plan, and problem-solve barriers.
sections.post_session: Care coordinator follows up to ensure services are delivered as planned.

short_term: Stabilization of behavioral and emotional issues

common: Service delivery challenges if systems are under-resourced

relative: Low engagement capacity of family or service providers

ideal_candidates: Children and adolescents with multi-system needs
Families facing risk of child removal or placement disruption
Youth with serious behavioral or emotional disorders
screening_required: Assessment of clinical and social service needs
Evaluation of family willingness to engage in care coordination

practitioner: Wraparound facilitators trained in care coordination and trauma-informed practices
facility: Community-based agencies, schools, child welfare systems, juvenile justice services

studies: Bruns, E. J., Walker, J. S., & The National Wraparound Initiative Advisory Group. (2010). The Resource Guide to Wraparound.
Suter, J. C., & Bruns, E. J. (2009). Effectiveness of the wraparound process for children with emotional and behavioral disorders: A meta-analysis.
sections.limitations: Effectiveness depends heavily on fidelity of implementation and inter-agency collaboration.

sections.typical_session_cost: Not session-based; cost varies by intensity of services
sections.total_treatment_cost: Variable depending on length of involvement and number of services included
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered through Medicaid, state mental health funding, or child welfare
sections.cost_effectiveness: Shown to be cost-effective by preventing expensive out-of-home placements and reducing hospitalizations

lifestyle_recommendations: Encouraging family participation in community activities

sections.children: Widely used for children with serious emotional and behavioral disturbances.
sections.adolescents: Effective for youth with multi-system involvement, especially juvenile justice.
sections.cultural: Wraparound emphasizes cultural competence and tailoring to family and community values.

items: Success relies on fidelity to wraparound principles, including family voice and choice.
Requires ongoing interagency collaboration and adequate resources.
Particularly effective in preventing foster care and residential placements.
